To use AUTO1111 to rename a batch of images in a directory on Windows, you can use the following steps:

Install AUTO1111 by running the following command in a terminal (such as PowerShell or the Command Prompt):

pip install auto1111

Open the terminal and navigate to the directory that contains the images you want to rename using the cd command.

Use the dir command to list the files in the directory. This will allow you to verify that the images you want to rename are present.

Use the for loop to iterate over the files in the directory and pass each file to AUTO1111 for renaming. Here is an example of how you could do this:

for %f in (*) do auto1111 "%f"

This script will iterate over all the files in the current directory, and for each file, it will pass the file to AUTO1111 for renaming. The renamed files will be saved in the same directory as the original files.

You can also use the -d flag to specify a destination directory for the renamed files, like this:

for %f in (*) do auto1111 "%f" -d C:\path\to\destination\directory

Note that the %f variable in the for loop represents the current file being processed.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: This is not the beginning of AI, this is
posts.com:
Almost all machine learning advancements required enormous compute and/or data. Almost all advancements in GPT, stable diffusion, deepmind's tech, they have been generated by pumping more and more compute and larger training sets to generate larger networks. There have been insights into different algorithms (like diffusion models), but these are negligible compared to the results generated from raw compute. This was summed up in "The Bitter Lesson" by Sutton.

In fact, exponentially more compute has been added to train these machines. Over the past 10 years, the amount of compute used to train models has doubled every ~3 months. And here's the key: Models do not exponentially increase despite exponentially more compute. The results are diminishing even with exponential compute.

The truth is, this is not the beginning. This is the end. We are witnessing the final works, squeezed out of the immense amount of compute brought on by Moore's Law over the past several decades. Moore's law is dead and there will never be such an exponential increase in compute again. Cope with it, muh 3d chips are never going to happen, muh neuromorphic computing is not going to bring the results needed, there is no next paradigm.
A similar thing happened with cars, and planes. There was an exponential increase in their efficiency and production, then it tapered off, never to increase in such a fashion again. We are already here when it comes to compute. We are not at the beginning, we're at the end. There is no law of accelerating returns.

The next 1-2 years we will see many cool AI apps coming out, none of which will be as radically game-changing as the proponents say, and then it will taper off due to the lack of power needed to produce greater results. Artificial General Intelligence will not be achieved, and we will never achieve a singularity. This is also why we do not see aliens; there is an upper bound to technology and we are almost there.

>>90594994
Depends on what you want to make, what style you wanted in, and how detailed you wanted to be. I haven't tried it so I don't take my word come up but I've heard that stable diffusion 2.0 is a heavily neutered version of the previous versions (because the people making and overseeing the models are spineless idiots). Novel AI and anything v3 have a noticeable anime bias (Even prompting something like "beautiful woman in a field" And literally nothing else will cause the face to look like it's drawn anime style) Well other models like stable diffusion and Elysium Do not. You may have to experiment with mixing different models at varying strengths to get the results you want. There's no one size fits I'll answer you're going to find from any of us. You have to play with it.

>>90594204
>where can i find elysmix
It's a custom mix, rather weird, requires the elysiumore checkpoint which is itself a horribly complicated merge with an unknown recipe

IF ANYONE HAS ELYSIUMORE RECIPE PLEASE POST IT

The instructions for elysmix1-variant0:
- Add difference @ 1.0: anything30, sfeb1, sd15
- Weighted sum @ 0.20: cafeinstagram, $_
- Weighted sum @ 0.20: elysiumore, $_

The instructions for elysmix1-variant1:
- Add difference @ 1.0: anything30, sfeb1, sd15
- Weighted sum @ 0.60: cafeinstagram, $_
- Weighted sum @ 0.40: elysiumore, $_

As is obvious, variant0 is very subtle, yet the two mixes are almost identical. variant0 is far superior to variant1, but variant1 can be more flexible but usually fails on human subjects.

>>90596305
well, the max additional + the base would be 0.9 denoise on the spikes. Since the script requires an iterative seed (add or subtract 1 every image) it get's to a seed that changes the pose completely and spikes the denoise to completely flip over. I'd say lower the max denoise and, if you are comfortable with keying it, flip the seed travel direction using the scripts prompt input. Hope this helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are maximum and minimum curve angles you can use for locomotive rail, depending on a bunch of factors.

Generally however larger steam locomotives like that need to have a pretty gentle curve, especially if they're going to go through at speed.


Shorter vehicles like streetcars/trams can do much tighter curves as they tend to move at lower speeds, and tend to have a much shorter wheelbase anyway.

>>90581403
If you've played with acoustic guitar you would notice that A440 tuning though it sounds familiar sounds bad but the thing is A440 seems to sound like the sound is happening from few inches outside your ear - if there's a way to describe it it's like someone is nagging right at your ears.

Once you tune intervals down to A439 (about 4% shift but realistically higher inverse square logarithms and shit) it's a lot better.
I've also noticed leaving guitar unused in tune usually shifts down to A420-435 and suddenly the low frequency vibrations of other notes can be felt from within. I don't have absoulte or relative pitch so it's not annoying to play with bunch of tunings for me. I also listen to different tuning with my music library and have at least developed the ability to blind test A440 apart from higher or lower semitone/cents.

The point is A440 doesn't sound natural but good thing is you can use software to set semitone/cent/Hz but sometimes not even the "songs" out there are dead ass A440.
I use a realtime FFT pitch app and noticed that a few songs out there are sometimes not actually A440 or have backing instruments untuned or tuned as just intonation sometimes.

It really doesn't matter what tuning you listen to but I've recently been going with A440 for all goyslop music and listening to lower A tuning with japshit and sometimes as high as A450 to some that sound very uplifting - the only problem is most music players use the inferior "rubberband" for shifting tones/semitones/cents and it sucks so bad.
Might have to program a music player myself to do the job and allow for each song its own tuning (mainly I use goysloppa440 for billboard shit).

>>90581403
>432Hz vs 440Hz
Makes no audible difference if you adjust all the audio equally.
>Does tuning really make a difference?
Yes.
First of all, there's a huge difference in feeling between 440Hz and 110Hz. And yes, tuning 440Hz down to 110Hz is technically tuning, I don't care that it's an entirely different note.
Secondly:
There's a lot more to tuning than just where you position the scale. Distances *within* the scale are also tuning (and frankly are the more interesting element of it).
For more info look up just intonation, equal temperament, and Pythagorean tuning. Sadly these days everyone's forgotten about just intonation and Pythagorean tuning and only uses equal temperament, but they actually sound different.
Quarter tone inclusive scales are an even wilder use of abnormal tuning. Consider the following chord: C, E half-flat, G. This is what's called a C neutral third chord. It's exactly in-between minor and major.

>pythagorean tuning is out of tune
Pythagorean tuning is not the same as just intonation. Pythagorean tuning is tuning using nothing but stacked fifths and octaves. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90584147
They'd hear it as an improvement, as people did with meantone. Consonance is mostly determined by the alignment of the partials of the notes. Very similar frequency is consonant. Far apart is consonant. Close together but obviously not the same frequency is dissonant. See Plomp and Levelt's 1965 paper "Tonal consonance and critical bandwidth". Average this over all possible pairs of partials, weighted by amplitude, and you get a good approximation of perceived consonance. See Sethares's 1993 paper "Local consonance and the relationship between timbre and scale".

Pythagorean tuning has the thirds in the wrong place to maximize consonance with harmonic timbres.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Musician here
A=432 reference is merely a meme nowadays but it has some uses.
432hz as portrayed in the image is a "less dense" tuning reference, meaning that your harmonic content will sound weaker, and that's the point, if you want to do ambient music or faggot shit like Pink Floyd and Co 432 is the way to go.
But if you want to make actual heavy music you can't even remotely think of ditching 440, which is the superior tuning reference for dense harmonic content.
For instance Hard EDM, Metal/Rock and similar.

Tip for you:
Pick a metal song you like and search for a 432hz version, you'll notice instantly the difference I explained before, so you can understand the paradigms of music theory more naturally.

*Harmonic content is a reference to the harmonics vs fundamental dB ratio of a single note of an instrument, the more harmonics an instrument has the more it will sound spiky/metallic or whatever depending on the material.
In a composing context it refers to the relations between low band and mid and high band the higher the mid and high band then the more harmonic content you have.
Broader sense: harmonics, always higher than the fundamental(1st harmonic).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90588316
Please stop playing music professionally - you're completely retarded and have zero concept of what the harmonic series and the timbral qualities of instruments are and how they actually relate to each other.

A) changing your tuning base frequency has practically zero impact on the harmonic series of an instrument. What it does impact, however, is the way in which a note may resonate within that instrument, and thus /which/ (not how many, like your regarded ass said) harmonics above the fundamental are ringing and at which dynamic. This is also something that you have to think about on a case by case basis - most instruments designed today do take in mind the A=440 standard, and thus, if the instrument maker is an absolute master, it is made to succeed in making sure that the soundwaves that travel through the instrument amplify the desired harmonics more. However, virtually all instruments that are the same (i.e. all Bb clarinets, not basset horns & bassoons) will have the same harmonic series, in a case where they are built under near identical conditions, /regardless/ of the tuning used.

B) the density of the harmonic series does not equate to a more "spiky/metallic" sound you fucking dumbass - like this anon said >>90588533 the cello is incredibly rich, and it does not sound neither spiky nor metallic - in fact, the cello is often said to be the instrument that most sounds like the human voice. the density simply equates to a denser and more "rich" (by virtue of # of harmonics above the fundamental) sound. The "metallic" quality comes from the instrument's material (and/or effects, if you're thinking about a guitar). Might I remind you that all synths are basically approximating certain real-life examples of sound to achieve their desired quality, and thus are still subject to these rules.

Please go learn more before continuing to play "music" you enormous retard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90592477
Because of the way the human ear works, dividing the octave into 12 parts gives a good selection of consonant intervals when using harmonic timbres, where are by far the most common timbres in music. Making those parts equal allows you to freely transpose and modulate with only a small sacrifice in consonance.

See https://sethares.engr.wisc.edu/consemi.html

You can do better, e.g. 53 EDO, or 72 EDO, but that adds a lot of complexity. 12EDO is simple enough that you can play it in real time on ordinary instruments. I wish 72 EDO was standard, but I can understand why it isn't.

>>90592563
>>90592605
I was asking because I wanted to know if I should bother answering. But anyway, this is a complicated question and linked to a huge rabbithole of knowledge about tuning systems. If you're interested, you should watch the relevant videos on Adam Neely's channel and try googling terms like "equal temperament", "historical temperaments". Unfortunately, this is made harder because of a significant amount of spiritual nonsense being attached to these topics, so you need to have your bullshit meter set on high.
Anyway, you probably know that while the particular frequencies like 440 Hz and 432 Hz are largely irrelevant, there are special ratios with characteristic sounds to the human brain. As a rule, simple fractions with small numbers like 3/2, 4/3, and 5/4 sound calm and consonant, while fractions like 133/101 sound unstable and dissonant. There used to be a lot of diversity in tuning, with many weird systems and instruments with differing number of keys per octave. The problem is that you can't create these perfect intervals everywhere with a finite number of keys. So if you make some intervals particularly nice and consonant, others get very dissonant and it becomes impossible to play a nice melody in some keys.
As time went on and music became more modern, people found it more important for all keys to be usable. Therefore everyone gradually changed to equal temperament, in which the frequencies are equally spaced by a ratio of the 12th root of 2. The number 12 is partially historical accident but also makes deep mathematical sense. If you enumerate the numbers N whose powers provide successively better approximations of simple fractions like 3/2, you get 5, 7, 12, 41, etc. 7 is too few for an intricate melody even from the medieval era, and it's impractical to make acoustic keyboard instruments with 41 keys per octave.

As for the black and white keys, the white keys are the scale of C Major, i.e. the keys that sound consonant when you hit them together with C. The choice of scale is largery arbitrary, but pianos being arranged this way is a very good thing in practice because it provides good visual and tactile reference. It would be harder to orient yourself on a piano which had only white keys or alternating black and white keys.

posts.com:
I suspect that tuning DOES matter. How much? no idea.

The argument against it mattering is that we all hear pitches "relatively". Even people with "perfect pitch" still hear music relatively. (i.e. people aren't listening to the actual pitches when they hear a melody, their brain is hearing the degree relatively the root/chord. For instance you don't E-D-C, you hear 3-2-1).

So tuning doesn't matter if we hear pitches relatively? Well honestly I think that's silly. Even though we hear pitches relatively, surely there differences, physiologically and otherwise that do matter.

Humans are physical beings after all. The inner ear is a physical structure. Surely some tuning systems produce better physiological reactions in the body than others, however minor these differences may be.

So my conclusion is that yes it probably does matter. Is the ideal tuning 432? No idea. Is it 440? no idea. Is the ideal tuning the same for all humans or does it differ between individuals? No idea. But I'm sure, at some level, it DOES make a difference.

>>90598252

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90598252
Yes, you lose some fuel to overlap, which is why carbureted 2 strokes haven't been able to meet emissions standards for 50+ years.

Modern direct injected 2 strokes fix this problem though, by not injecting fuel until the exhaust port is closed. Check out the Ski-Doo ETEC engines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90598252
There's an intake valve that opens on the up-stroke where fuel and air actually enters the crank case first, hence why 2-strokes can be lubricated through just a premix of fuel and oil. The valve closes on the downstroke after the old air is exhausted out, meaning there's no longer a vacuum in the cylinder and air-fuel from the crank case is then prted to the combustion chamber. You will see some loss still but that's just the crude nature of 2-strokes. Less heavy valves to move means a relatively high power-to-weight ratio so you do get quite a bit of efficiency back.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90598335
>which is why carbureted 2 strokes haven't been able to meet emissions standards for 50+ years.
That and the total loss lubraction means a lot of oil is in that exhaust on both the up stroke and downstroke. Direct oil injection has made this less of an issue though

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90598252
2-strokes rely on incredibly short stroke pistons to minimize these loses in favor of a smaller cycle to acheive higher revs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90598252
Yes, there will always be a loss. The exhaust system is often designed so that sound waves reflect back into the combustion chamber just so so that the gasses tend to stay there for the upstroke. It's part of why those engines sound like that.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90598252
There's also always going to be a little bit of unburned reserved fuel-oil mixture down in the crank case as well that's always being picked back up, so while there is some loss from a 2-stroke system, all things considered it's very minimal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90598252
yes you lose some of the charge out the exhaust and back through the intake
you reduce this by using tuned exhaust pipes that create pressure waves that force the lost charge back into the combustion chamber and using reed valves in the intake that close when exposed to back pressure

it is not a net loss as the time both ports are uncovered is very short as the engine is spinning way faster than in the animation and so the charge lacks the velocity to escape completely
